body.p: Abstract of contract between H.C. D. Judah
and M. N. Nathan

The said Congn. engaged to pay M. N. N. $2500 P annum during
the term of his ability to perform the services required of him so long
as his behaviour shall not be regarded and considered as unbecoming
a minister of the Jewish Congregation. Salary to be paid in monthly
instalments if desired.

In consideration of such salary M. N. N. shall perform
the regular services in the Synagogue as Hazan or Reader
according to the customs of the Spanish & Portuguese Jews, commonly
called “Minhag Sephardim.” as well as those duties usually
performed out of Synagogue, and devolving customarily on Jewish
ministers; and it shall further be obligatory on M. N. N.
to deliver a sermon, discourse, or lecture in the English language
Every Sabbath, and the first day of every Jewish Festival or
Holy day, as well as on all occasions of General rejoicing
or Humiliation prescribed by the civil authorities of the land.

It is also agreed that the said Mr. N. N. shall
perform no religious service or religious ceremony out of the
Synagogue for any member of this above named Synagogue, or for
any other person without the written order of its presiding officer.

It is further understood that this contract is entered
into under the present existing constitution Laws and Regulations
of the said Hebrew Congregation “Dispd. of Judah.”

This contract, signed in Duplicate/shall
' commence from this first day of Feby 1850. 5610.
Signed M. N. Nathan
G. Kursheedt Preside.
Memoradum

This contract was entered into in accordance with resolution of Congregation
of Jany. 24Th 1850. specifying “that after Judah Louis Esq. Shall sign the act
of donation of the Synagogue, the Presidt. shall contract with Revd. M. N. N.
“for his services as Hazan & Preacher to their congregation during the term of his
“good behavior and ability (temporary sickness not to interfere) to perform
“the services generally conducted by persons occupying the like positions”
“the minister to be bound to give six months notice in writing of his intention
to resign his office.” And be it further enacted “That any member

of this Congn. making any charge or charges against the minister
shall do so in writing, and shall present the same to the board
of officers, who shall if they deem it necessary convene the body
at large stating the object of the meeting, and notify the minister
to attend to defend himself; a vote of three fourths of the justified
members present shall have power to suspend or remove him from
office Isaac Soria
Secy.
My dear Leeser

Herewith you have copy of my contract with
the congregation. You know me too well to suppose that I would have
accepted any engagement under the the dictatorial order of “sign or
resign.” Nor would our mutual friend Gershom Kursheedt have
allowed himself to be the medium of such a communication.

The provision relative to the preaching was my own act.
In the contract drawn up by G. K. I was to preach whenever the Presidt.
called on me to do so. However safe I might have been with the article
so worded with G. K. as Presidt., it might have been made a vehicle
of annoyance under a Presidt. inimical? to me, and therefore rejected
it. The last resolution of the Congregation is fair and reasonable
and prevents the body from condemning me whereas; its silence on
the subject of fire? is also in my favor. I must either be acquitted
or removed; there is no middle course. Another point is also liable
to remarking—viz—that I must be a party consulted should any alterations
in the present existing Laws and Regulations be entered upon, affecting
me personally. I am protected under any emergency.

The universal feeling of indignation pervades the Jews,
in this city at the shameful treatment of your late congregation towards
you. My advice to you is do not embark in a weekly paper. It will
not pay. Go into business, if not at the north-at the South. Doff the gown
which you have honored for twenty years. It will reflect no disgrace on
you to engage in business. Either as Revd. or plain Mr. you can serve your people.

Our Holy days went off harmoniously, as tho' we had been established
for a quarter of a century.

All your friends including Mrs. N. and myself wish you
success and prosperity, health and happiness in whatever you undertake
Your's affectionately

My most worthy friend will excuse the lack of
my usual punctuality in replying to his last
recd. form, when I state that the frequent
occurence of Holidays have kept me very
much occupied during the remainder of the
time. I hope what is set forth on the
annexed page (all which I endorse) will
satisfy you and your friends that certain
expressions have been attributed to me which
I never uttered. The Constitution & By Laws
of the Congregation are there I exhibited to you
when in Philadelphia, although they are
now about to be altered. You will recollect
that in our laws there is no mention made
of a Hazan, wherefore the resolution of the
congregation given on the preceeding page
was necessary to enable me to enter into
contract with Mr. Nathan.

The comse purused toward you by a
portion of your congregation meets with
the universal censure of our people here
and to my certain knowledge it is severely
commented upon in many parts of the
Union. Never mind friend Leeser your
good acts will outlive the memory of your
persecutors. It is the fate of the good to
have enemies. King David had many, none
but the insignificant move through the world
undisturbed. I hope always to have some
unfriendly acquaintances, they do us good.
There are men who delight in bringing their
superior down to their own level, but they
rarely succeed. I could write volumes on this subject
but it is not necessary, you know the sentiments of your friend
